thread.title: Ryanair passenger leaves plane to get into a limousine
thread.title_full: Ryanair passenger leaves plane to get into a limousine | Daily Mail Online

author: John Hutchinson for MailOnline
title: Ryanair passenger leaves plane to get into a limousine
text:
33 shares 11
View
comments
This is the ironic moment a limousine parked up next to a Ryanair plane to collect a passenger from his flight.
Photographed by a passenger waiting in the terminal building for a flight back to the UK, the plane had landed at Berlin Schoenfeld in Germany around 4.10pm local time yesterday.
Some 20 minutes later, as the passengers left the plane, a man believed to be in his 40s, disembarked via the rear exit, got into the limousine, and the car sped off.
Scroll down for video
The limousine came round the back of the Ryanair plane as passengers disembarked at Berlin Schoenfeld
Once the passenger, a man in his 40s according to the photographer, had got in, the car drove off
Customers can fly from London to Berlin Schoenfeld with the budget carrier from as a little as £14.99 each way.
Padraig Prendergast, who was waiting for his flight to Stansted, told MailOnline Travel: 'As I was queuing I looked out the window to the left and saw a white limo circle the Ryanair flight I was about to get on.
 Next Explore the canals, enjoy the local jazz music scene and... Family speaks of shock after arriving at Airbnb villa in... The heart-warming moment a little lion cub practised his... Easy rider: How anyone can turn themselves into a Tour de... 33 shares 'A man got into the stretch car and it turned around on the tarmac and did a couple of loops around the back of the plane before veering off underneath the terminal.
'No one else seemed phased about the bizarre pick up and I seemed to be the only one shocked who managed to quickly take some photos.
'I mean really, who gets a Ryanair flight and then hops into a limo? The irony.'
The passenger who photographed the incident said he was surprised no-one else thought it was ironic
Flights from London to Berlin Schoenfeld in Germany cost as little as £14.99 each way
MailOnline Travel believes the flight, that had landed at Gate 10, had flown in from London Stansted. Mr Prendergast was flying back to Stansted from the same gate.
A spokesperson for Ryanair told MailOnline Travel: 'It just goes to show how much our customers save: book the lowest fares with Ryanair, and spend like a rock star when you get there.'
MailOnline Travel has contacted Berlin Schoenfeld Airport for comment, and is awaiting their response.
Ryanair to hand £300m to investors after receiving windfall from offloading Aer Lingus stake Ryanair will hand almost £300million back to its shareholders after receiving a windfall from offloading its stake in Aer Lingus.
The Irish carrier owned 29.8 per cent of its domestic rival, and launched takeover bids for the whole airline.
But these were thwarted by competition authorities, who also told Ryanair to sell its stake down to below 5 per cent. Earlier this year it agreed to sell the holding to IAG as part of the British Airways owner's £1billion takeover of Aer Lingus.
Offloading: Ryanair agreed to sell its Aer Lingus holding to IAG earlier this year
Ryanair said it would distribute the proceeds, some £295million, to shareholders this year.
It brings the amount handed back to Ryanair investors to £590million, and a total of £2.4billion since 2008 – and caps the airline's sterling summer.
The company increased its annual profit expectations by 25 per cent earlier this month following a bumper holiday season that saw it take more UK travellers across Europe.
Airlines are enjoying tailwinds caused by the global oil price dip.
Fuel costs are a major factor affecting airlines' razor-thin margins. Rival EasyJet has also hiked its profit expectations to as high as £700million from between £620million-£660million.
Ryanair, stung by two profits warnings in 2013, has overhauled its business model by being nice to customers and cutting out controversial hidden charges. It also made its website easier to use.
